sections.title: Retirement Account Options
sections.content: Traditional retirement accounts (Traditional IRA, 401(k)) provide tax deductions on contributions but withdrawals are taxed as ordinary income. Roth accounts (Roth IRA, Roth 401(k)) are funded with after-tax dollars but provide tax-free growth and withdrawals. Choose based on your current vs. future tax situation.

points.title: Traditional Accounts
points.description: Tax deduction now, taxable withdrawals later - best if you expect to be in a lower tax bracket in retirement.

points.title: Roth Accounts
points.description: No tax deduction now, tax-free withdrawals later - best if you expect higher taxes in retirement.

points.title: HSA Accounts
points.description: Triple tax advantage: deductible contributions, tax-free growth, tax-free withdrawals for medical expenses.

sections.title: Contribution Limits Matter
sections.content: For 2023: 401(k) $22,500, IRA $6,500, HSA $3,850 (individual). Contribute as much as possible to maximize tax benefits and compound growth.

sections.title: Education Savings Accounts
sections.content: 529 plans offer tax-free growth and withdrawals for qualified education expenses. Contributions are not federally deductible but may be state deductible. Coverdell ESAs have lower contribution limits but more investment flexibility.

sections.title: Reevaluate Annually
sections.content: Your tax situation and account options may change. Review your contribution strategy each year and adjust based on income changes or new account availability.
